I really think it's a shame th=
at insights such as these often don't get
published. Only shows that some p=
arts of the community have an overly
narrow view of what constitutes a rese=
arch publication. Sometimes
these kinds of things make it into textbooks, t=
hus becoming widely
known and the author getting some acknowledgement. In o=
ther cases, it
just doesn't get published.

Another example: Just last week=
 at CEC we discussed the simple but
powerful idea that you should scramble =
your population before sorting
(or use a non-order-preserving sorting algor=
ithm) in a normal
Evolution Strategy to encourage exploitation of neutralit=
y in the
search space. Many people have discovered this independently (most=
 of
them before me), but nobody has written it up, as (a) it's too simple,
=
so someone else must have found it first (true) and (b) it's not
"research"=
. Still, the idea is missing from standard textbooks and
overview articles,=
 and nobody can't point to a systematic study of how
it improves search.

>=
Maybe we can talk more about
> the idea of such an article at the symposium=
.

Let's do that!

Julian
